X.T: personal notes
.NET Delegates: Making Asynchronous Method Calls in the .NET Environment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to delegates and how to call them asynchronously.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of .NET for Perl developers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A book to learn C#.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The difference between implicit and explicit interface implementations.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed description of yield.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Misceallaneous subjects: early access via CodePlex, how to support the multiple .NET languages, code contracts…

X.T: Named and Optional Parameters in C# 4.0

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation of the feature.

X.T: How Do I: Use Covariance and Contravariance in VS 2010 Part I?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the limitations of the previous C# versions.

X.T: How Do I: Use Covariance and Contravariance in VS 2010 Part II?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to declare covariant and contravariant interfaces and delegates.

X.T: C# 4.0 grammar

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to navigate the C# hyperlinked grammar.

X.T: Understanding C#: Equality, IEquatable, and Equals()

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: How Attributes Can Help You Debug an App
X.ST: Learn how attribute-driven programming can help debug and maintain your applications much more efficiently

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using attributes to define how the debugger displays data (DebuggerDisplayAttribute, DebuggerBrowsableAttribute, and DebuggerTypeProxyAttribute) and how it steps into methods (DebuggerStepThroughAttribute and DebuggerHiddenAttribute).

X.T: Introduction to Tuples in .NET Framework 4.0

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation to Tuple.

X.T: Introducing Code Access Security in .NET Framework

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A too short introduction to Code Access Security.

X.T: Introduction to Memory Mapped Files

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short introduction to MemoryMappedFile.

X.T: .NET Framework: Corrupted State Exceptions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: With .NET 4, corrupted process state exceptions are delivered anymore to managed code.

X.T: .NET Framework: Use Your Own Cache Wrapper to Help Performance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very simple code sample to keep cached data in the HttpContext’s cache and some bad advice: using a static object makes the code difficult to be unit tested.

X.T: Demystifying C# Programming's ToString Method

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A little information about ToString(). The argument on using it to get more readable information in Visual Studio is dubious, DebuggerDisplayAttribute should be used instead.

X.T: C# Back to Basics: Static Constructors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Understanding the Dynamic Keyword in C# 4

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the dynamic keyword with many pointers toward more detailed information.

X.T: Anders Hejlsberg: Questions and Answers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Miscellaneous questions to the C# creator.

X.T: .NET Framework: Collections and Generics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This presentation of generics is much too short, unclear, and contains some errors (e.g. the boxing/unboxing definition).

X.T: Jon Mccoy - Hacking .Net Applications: The Black Arts

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The guy is probably good technically, but the demos are unprepared and unclear, the speech about hacking vs. defending yourself is non-understandable…

X.T: The New Read-Only Collections in .NET 4.5

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quick presentation of IReadOnlyList, IReadOnlyDictionary and IReadOnlyCollection.

X.T: Using NRefactory for analyzing C# code

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very technical introduction to NRefactory.

X.T: Understanding .NET Using Read-Only Collections
X.ST: Even if you're not working in the Microsoft .NET Framework 4.5, .NET provides you with a way to create a read-only collection or to convert an existing List into a read-only collection.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to implement a read-only list in .NET 4.0.

X.T: Microsoft Enterprise Library helps .NET developers be more productive
X.ST: The Microsoft Enterprise Library offers reusable software components to assist with building .NET applications. Learn how to contribute to one or more of its projects.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of Microsoft Enterprise Library.

X.T: What's New In .NET 2015

ARTICLE.COMMENT: .NET Native, new ASP.NET and Roslyn.

X.T: The IsNullOrWhiteSpace trap

ARTICLE.COMMENT: string.IsNullOrWhiteSpace and string.IsNullOrEmpty are dangerous, they tend to make developers handle null and blank strings the same way, while, most often, this should not be the case.

X.T: Caching Regular Data Benefits Regular Programs, Too

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very simple example of using System.Runtime.Caching.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JetBrains announces its own C# IDE.

X.T: Project Rider

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Project Rider announcement during NDC London.

X.T: Treating warnings as errors to help prevent technical debt

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Configuring projects so warnings are treated as errors except for using a method flagged with the Obsolete attribute.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Microsoft creates a C# Technical Steering Group and Red Hat, JetBrains and Unity are joining it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A much too short and basic introduction to Unity.

X.T: Replace a Running Application with a New Version

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How a program can replace its own file.

X.T: What’s behind the hype about Blazor?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of Blazor.

X.T: Write Once, Run Everywhere with .NET and the Uno Platform
X.ST: Right now, in Visual Studio, you can create a solution that takes a single UI with its code and shares it across Windows, Android, macOS, iOS and web browsers. It's not a perfect cross-platform solution (yet), but it's here now.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information (mostly details on creating a projet in Visual Studio) about Uno.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Automatic properties, implicitly typed variables, object initialisers, collection initialisers, LINQ & anonymous types, lambda expressions, and extension methods.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Roslyn and some new C# 5 features.

X.T: What's Cool in C# 8 and .NET Core 3

X.T: How to Get Started with Multi-Core: Parallel Processing You Can Use

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short overview of Task.

X.T: How to Parallelize Your Application - Part 1 Why Do It?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The very familiar explanation of why applications now need to be multithreaded: CPUs cannot have a higher frequency, so they have an increasing number of cores instead.

X.T: How to Parallelize Your Application - Part 2 Threads v Tasks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The explanation of the differences between threads and tasks.

X.T: How to Parallelize Your Application - Part 3 Using Tasks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the three ways to use tasks: imperative task parallelism (using System.Threading.Tasks), imperative data parallelism (using parallel For, ForEach, Invoke from System.Threading.Tasks.Parallel), and declarative data parallelism (using PLINQ).

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A too short presentation of three ways to implement multi-threading: BackgroundWorker, Control.BeginInvoke, and implementing the IAsyncResult interface.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to TPL Data Parallel.
